conclusion: Objects A and B move through the air and are placed down at the location of objects C, D, E, F, coming into contact due to gravity.
Objects A and B are visually depicted as moving downward toward a stack of objects labeled C, D, E, and F, which are upright on a surface.
Objects A and B travel downward until they reach the level where C, D, E, and F are standing.
On contact, the impulse from the moving objects A and B is greater than the static stability of the upright stack of C, D, E, and F.
The stack of C, D, E, and F cannot resist the sideways/disturbing force caused by the impact of A and B, so it tips over.
All pieces, including C, D, E, F, A, and B, collapse and end up lying on the surface rather than standing upright.
